awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Electromyography (EMG)-Based Assistive Human-Machine Interface Design: Cognitive Workload and Motor Skill Learning Assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Electromyography (EMG)-based Assistive Human-Machine Interface Design: Cognitive Workload and Motor Skill Learning Assessment

Over 100,000 people in the United States have upper limb amputations. Such amputations are usually associated with substantial disabilities. Activities of daily living may no longer be possible or require additional effort and time. To restore functional ability as fully as possible, amputee patients use upper-limb prostheses controlled by Electromyography (EMG)-based human-machine interfaces (HMIs). However, over 50% of prosthetic users report device dissatisfaction and abandonment due to frustration in use. In order to increase accessibility and utility of EMG-based assistive HMIs, it is critical to investigate the cognitive workload associated with using these systems for supporting motor skill rehabilitation and activities of daily living. In addition, with differences in individual muscle make-up and control, it is necessary to customize EMG-based assistive HMIs to particular patient conditions. However, at this time, there exists little to no general guidance on what interface control features may be more or less conducive to supporting learning and performance of psychomotor tasks. By testing various control interface prototypes in a validated motor skill learning simulation as well as high-demand, real-time tasks, specifically simulated driving, the investigators seek to provide design guidance for engineers to develop EMG-based assistive HMI technologies for various applications. This project also provides education and training for young industrial, computer science, and biomedical engineering students in assistive technology design and development.

The technical aims of the project are divided into three thrusts including (1) identifying cognitive load costs of EMG-based HMIs using computational cognitive performance models and machine learning algorithms - The developed cognitive workload models will be used for predicting learning potential and performance outcomes of variations of control interface designs, (2) demonstrating fundamental motor skill training through integration of the EMG-based HMI with virtual reality (VR) simulations - In particular, the investigators are interested in assessing whether the difference in cognitive load of using EMG-based HMIs translates to variations in learning potential and retention of psychomotor task skills, (3) translating fundamental motion components trained in the VR psychomotor test to a real-world application by demonstrating the possibility of operational driving control with an EMG-based HMI in a high-fidelity driving simulator - This thrust provides empirical validation for the findings regarding differences in cognitive load of using EMG-based HMIs, as well as the potential for increased learning and operational task performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research developed engineering and design guidance for electromyography (EMG)-based assistive human-machine interfaces (HMIs) to support human performance in basic psychomotor tasks and real-time, high-demand control activities. Key results and their implications are outlined below.

(1) We developed cognitive task performance models for predicting prosthetic user cognitive workload. Through our empirical studies, we found that cognitive performance models (CPM), subjective measures, task performance measures, and some physiological measures were sensitive in detecting cognitive workload differences among prosthetic device configurations and therefore, could be useful tools in usability evaluation of these technologies. However, to reduce intrusiveness and cost, methods such as subjective workload measures, task performance, and CPM are more beneficial as compared to physiological measurements. The proposed guidelines can be beneficial to select the most appropriate workload measurement techniques to improve sensitivity and accuracy and reduce intrusiveness and cost.

(2) Another contribution of this study was the development of a task selection strategy and a comprehensive test battery to evaluate the usability of upper-limb prosthetic devices. Through a combined literature review, sensitivity analysis, and an examination of essential upper-limb movements, the research identified the clothespin relocation task (CRT) and Southampton hand assessment protocol (SHAP) as the most sensitive testbeds for usability assessment of upper-limb prosthetic devices. These tasks require similar limb movements to high frequency activities of daily living.

(3) The research explored the use of machine learning (ML) algorithms to predict cognitive workload in prosthetic device prototypes early in the design process. Three ML algorithms, including the random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), and naive Bayesian (NB) classifier were developed. The findings suggested that task performance measures, pupillometry data, and CPM outcomes, combined with the naive bayes (NB) and random forest (RF) algorithms, are most promising for classifying cognitive workload. The proposed algorithms can help manufacturers and clinicians predict the cognitive workload of future EMG-based prosthetic devices in early design phases.

(4) While virtual reality (VR) is frequently used to train amputees on prosthetic device operation, its impact on usability and cognitive workload had not been studied before. This research compared cognitive workload and usability of VR simulations of EMG-based prosthetics to actual physical devices. Results showed that VR simulations can reduce cognitive workload and improve perceived usability, suggesting VR as a viable option for prosthetic training that also improves the user experience and ease of learning.

(5) To inform the design of user-friendly prosthetic devices, this study compared three EMG-based control modes: direct control (DC), pattern recognition (PR), and continuous control (CC) for their effects on user task performance, cognitive workload, and usability. Using diverse human-centered assessments and two test tasks (CRT and SHAP), results revealed performance with each control mode to vary among tasks. When the task had high-angle adjustment accuracy requirements, the PR control outperformed DC. Both CC and PR control appear to be effective alternatives to DC in terms of task performance and cognitive load. Also, when comparing control modes, multitask testing and multifaceted evaluations are critical to avoid task-induced or method-induced evaluation bias.

(6) The research introduced the Human Performance Model for Upper-Limb Prosthetic Devices (HPM-UP), which uses measures such as learnability, error rate, memory load, efficiency, and user satisfaction to predict usability. A validation experiment using a bypass prosthetic device demonstrated the model's ability to predict usability when compared to human performance data. Available for use in Rstudio via GitHub, the model provides a quantitative method for clinicians and researchers to assess and compare various commercial prostheses, potentially guiding users toward optimal device recommendations.

(7) We demonstrated the integration of an EMG-based HMI with a commercially available driving simulator software. The integration allowed for users to perform basic operational driving tasks as well as some tactical maneuvers, including passing and turns at intersections. Although the HMI did not facilitate driving performance superior to conventional methods (hand steering), the study identified interface cognitive workload and usability issues that may direct further research for EMG-based HMI enhancement and application in real time dynamic control tasks.

Broader Impacts of the Research

The outcomes of this research extend beyond intellectual contributions to practical applications in assistive technology, education, and user-centered design. Broader impacts include the following:

(1) Enhanced Rehabilitation and Daily Living Support: This research improves the potential utility of EMG-based HMIs in rehabilitating motor skills and supporting daily tasks for populations with upper-limb amputations.

(2) Applications in Realistic Virtual Training Environments: The usability of EMG-based HMIs was evaluated for applications in virtual worlds and psychomotor task training systems, expanding possibilities for able-bodied users and specialized applications.

(3) Education and Training for Students: The research provided extensive training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in industrial engineering and computer science, equipping them with skills in EMG-based HMI design, cognitive workload analysis, and VR simulation development. Such training prepares them for careers in assistive technology innovation.
